Reuse Learning Objects through LOM and XML Lars Arne Skår Thomas Heiberg Vidar Kongsli System architect 
Portal developer Content integrator BEKK Consulting AS, P.O. Box 134 BEKK Consulting AS, P.O. Box 134

ABSTRACT This document describes how the Norwegian education portal (www.utdanning.no) uses XML and the 
Learning Object Metadata standard (LOM) to integrate existing providers of learning objects into one 
common search portal. LOM is an IEEE standard (IEEE 1484.12.1) for categorizing and describing learning 
objects [1]. Categories and Subject Descriptors H.3.7 [Digital Libraries]: Collection, Standards, Systems 
issues, User issues H.3.3 [Information Search and Retrieval]: Query formulation, Search process, Selection 
process H.3.5 [Online Information Services]: Data sharing, web-based services K.3.1 [Computer Uses 
in Education]: Distance learning, Computer-assisted instruction (CAI) Internet, Web, Java, Systems Application 
Architecture, XML General Terms Management, Reliability, Human Factors, Standardization Keywords IEEE, 
learning objects, standardization, LOM, integration, XML 1. INTRODUCTION The Norwegian ministry of education 
and research is currently establishing an education portal (www.utdanning.no) as part of the national 
learning net for the education sector. One major goal of this initiative is to enable better reuse and 
sharing of learning objects on the internet. The portal is developed by BEKK, a Norwegian consultancy 
focusing on portal development. Although the Norwegian learning community has an abundance of learning 
resources available already - through initiatives from teachers, students and the like, they are hard 
to find and quality varies. Currently resources are typically made available from commercial eLearning 
vendors, school projects and lately also a combination of public and privately funded learning portals 
on specific areas. To make these resources more easy to find, and available with a consistent level of 
quality, the education portal will provide a searchable catalogue of learning resources through a common 
search interface. For this to work, the portal has to index the resources from different providers of 
learning resources, which again has to follow a common vocabulary and categorization. Here lays the real 
challenge indexing resources with different formats from different technology platforms, and getting 
the learning resource providers on board as smoothly as possible; i.e. with least amount of burden on 
their side. The challenges can be summarized as follows: Common searchable catalogue of learning resources 
 Establishing a common vocabulary and categorization of resources  Establishing an infrastructure for 
learning resource providers  Handling different formats and technology platforms  2. THE SOLUTION 
XML over HTTP was established as the transportation protocol. This solves the technology challenges and 
infrastructure challenges, as it is practically always supported, and ensures interoperability across 
content providers. Having overcome the technical challenges, the focus turned to the domain/data level; 
i.e. how to make data on learning resources from different providers available in a consistent format 
for searching and indexing. A simple web crawling mechanism would not work, because meta-data on learning 
resources typically are not available on the web sites, or they are inconsistent and lack the precision 
needed. The solution on domain/data consistency was to follow established standards on the subject; i.e. 
the Learning Object Metadata (LOM) standard - IEEE 1484.12.1[1]. The standard was approved December 10, 
2002 and defines a meta-model to categorize and describe learning objects. Although well received, and 
internationally recognized, adoption is still in its early stages, which again required the project to 
define the actual use of the standard in collaboration with local and European standardization bodies 
(www.estandard.no, cetis.ac.uk ) [2] [3]. This standard has been used in Canada (www.cancore.ca) and 
UK Copyright is held by the author/owner(s). (www.curriculumonline.gov.uk) -thus the Norwegian education 
OOPSLA 03, October 26 30, 2003, Anaheim, California, USA. portal could benefit from their experiences, 
but still had to ACM 1-58113-751-6/03/0010. develop their own application profile, as this is linked 
to the local content in itself. 2.1 The data exchange standard Indevelopingthe application profile for 
the education portal, the goalwas to establish a minimalist standard, but still flexible enough to prepare 
for the near future. Thus, the focus was on enabling search within the portal, and establishingaconsistent 
standardized XML-format for the learning providers. Thus, only 21 of the 90 fields from the LOM standardwasused, 
as these were considered essential for searching and providing the most important information for the 
users of theportal. Ofthese, we consider the classification fields to be of criticalimportance, as theyare 
usedto categorize the learning resources into a navigational structure. The categorization is maintained 
in aseparateXML-fileto ensure that they are categorized into the same classification system.Asa basis 
for the classification system, the portal editorial board decided to use the Norwegian learning plan, 
which describes goals for learning within each subject for eachschool level. The following illustrates 
how this file is defined. <classifications> <source name="Primary school"> <maincategory name="Mathematics"> 
 <subcategory1 name="Daily Mathematics"/> <subcategory1 name="Numbers"/> <subcategory1 name="Space 
and shape"/> <subcategory1 name="Others"/> </maincategory>  2.2 Navigation and searching The navigation 
follows a traditional search form, list and detail fashion. The following illustrates the current design.

Figure 1: Navigation and searching user interface The portalandsearchinterface was developed with a 
portal framework;IBM WebspherePortal Server, which made it effective to develop this functionality within 
the portal; i.e. the search interface was implemented as a portlet (extended servlet). The searchitself 
is performed through a search engine; Verity K2, which indexes the learning resources metadataasspecified 
earlier. Verity is accessed from the portal through a Java API. To utilize the search engine in this 
fashion, themedataon resources have to be transformed to a formthatworkwith the search engine. This means 
splitting the metadata file into separate documentsfor each learning resource so that the search engine 
can find the individual resources through its search function.  3. THEARCHITECTURE Learning Learning
